Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A devastating landslide in the Tibet Autonomous Region buried 83 workers from Tibet Huatailong Mining Development Co. Ltd. on Friday morning, according to Xinhua News Agency. The incident occurred around 6 a.m. in Maizhokunggar County, east of Lhasa, and the victims included two Tibetans. The landslide, which extended three kilometers and consisted of 2 million cubic meters of debris, was caused by a sudden collapse of a mountain slope.

Sure! Here's the story summarized in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

The US and Libyan governments held face-to-face talks in Tunisia, with the sole purpose of the meeting being for the US to demand that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go." The meeting was the first step towards discussing ideas to end the conflict and repair the damaged relationship between the two countries. The US official familiar with the meeting emphasized that Gadhafi's departure is a non-negotiable condition for any resolution. The Libyan government spokesman welcomed further steps towards a resolution, but there is no comment from Washington on the report.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Canada has officially renounced the Kyoto Protocol, citing unworkable goals without the participation of the United States and China. Environment Minister Peter Kent stated that Canada will continue to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and work towards a new global agreement. The decision was met with criticism from the opposition party, who accused the government of standing up for big polluters and risking the country's reputation. Despite this, Kent maintains that Canada is committed to reducing emissions by 17% by 2020.

Sure! Here is the story summarized in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Faezeh Hashemi, daughter of former Iranian president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has been sentenced to six months in prison for participating in anti-government protests. She was arrested last year and will serve her sentence in a relatively comfortable section of Evin prison. Her father is a powerful cleric and former parliament speaker who has been a vocal critic of the government. This sentencing is seen as a sign of the government's ongoing crackdown on dissent.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Colton Harris-Moore, known as the "Barefoot Bandit," pleaded not guilty to six federal charges during a court appearance. His lawyer said they are working on a plea agreement and restitution amount, which is expected to be around $1.3 million. Harris-Moore gained notoriety for allegedly stealing boats, cars, and planes while eluding police capture, and has a loyal fan base on Facebook. Possible book and movie deals are in the works, with the proceeds going to the victims. The trial is set to begin on July 11.

Here's the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Cpl. Trent D. Thomas, a Marine, was sentenced to a rank reduction and discharge for his role in the death of an Iraqi civilian. Thomas was found guilty of kidnapping and conspiracy charges related to the death of Hashim Ibrahim Awad in 2006. Prosecutors allege that the group's squad leader, Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, dragged Awad from his home and shot him in the street. Thomas originally pleaded guilty but later changed his plea, arguing that he was merely following orders. He will be demoted to the rank of entry-level private and receive a bad-conduct discharge.

Sure! Here's the story summarized in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A poultry facility in Missouri was quarantined after a suspected case of bird flu was discovered during routine testing. The facility will be tested further to confirm the presence of the virus, and up to 15,000 younger turkeys will be euthanized as a precaution. The state emphasizes that it is extremely rare for humans to be affected by this type of bird flu. The U.S. Agriculture Department is monitoring the situation.

Sure! Here's the story in under 150 words while preserving coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A mayoral candidate in Paris has proposed transforming the city's disused metro stations into vibrant underground spaces. Illustrations show possibilities such as swimming pools, nightclubs, and art installations. One candidate, Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet, has commissioned the designs to revitalize Arsenal, a ghost metro stop since 1939. If elected, she'll ask Parisians for their ideas to transform the vacant spaces. The proposal aims to breathe new life into the city's underground, but the frontrunner in the race, Socialist Anne Hidalgo, still leads in the polls.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

David Headley, born Daood Gilani, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for his role in the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed 164 people. He changed his name to facilitate surveillance in India and cooperated with U.S. authorities, providing valuable intelligence on terrorist activities. Prosecutors recommended a 30-35 year sentence in exchange for his plea on terrorism charges. The Indian government seeks to conduct another trial, but the U.S. will not extradite Headley to any other country. His cooperation has helped combat terrorism, according to the U.S. Attorney's office.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy has condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at an army checkpoint in the Rafah border crossing in Sinai, promising to capture those responsible. At least 15 soldiers were killed and 9 others wounded when masked assailants attacked the checkpoint during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have blamed terrorists associated with the Global Jihad group for the violence. The attackers attempted to infiltrate into Israel, leading to a gunbattle and the closure of the border crossing. Morsy has vowed to impose full control over the affected areas, calling the attack an "ugly crime." Hamas has also condemned the attack and closed all border tunnels connecting Gaza with Egypt.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A bomb blast in Kano, Nigeria killed at least four people and injured several others. The explosion occurred in a predominantly Christian area and left several cars burning. Police have cordoned off the area and are searching for suspects and any additional bombs. The identity of the perpetrator is unknown, but the attack highlights the ongoing terrorism concerns in Nigeria, particularly since the kidnapping of over 200 school girls by Boko Haram in April.

Sure! Here is the story summarized in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

NASA's Space Shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week to the International Space Station, carrying a crew of seven astronauts and a special treadmill named after comedian Stephen Colbert. The mission will be Discovery's 37th to space and the 30th dedicated to assembling and maintaining the space station. The treadmill, named COLBERT, will help astronauts stay fit in space. Launch is scheduled for 1:36 a.m. ET Tuesday, but may be delayed due to weather or technical concerns.

Six unidentified men were discovered in a cargo truck during a random security sweep at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport. The men were found to be illegal immigrants from Mexico and El Salvador, and they had no ill intent against the US. The security operation was part of a routine exercise carried out at various transportation hubs, using X-ray machines, radiological detection equipment, and bomb-sniffing canine teams. The investigation is ongoing, and the men have not yet been processed for removal from the US.

Lt. Gen. Karl Eikenberry, a career military officer, is expected to be appointed as the next U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan. If approved, he plans to bring his wife, Ching, with him to the war-torn country. However, the State Department has designated Afghanistan as an "unaccompanied post" due to safety concerns, which means family members are not allowed. Senator John Kerry, who is chairing Eikenberry's confirmation hearing, expressed support for Eikenberry's request, but there was no immediate reaction from the State Department.

Sure! Here is the story summarized in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

First Lady Michelle Obama will campaign in Iowa next month to support Democratic candidate Bruce Braley in one of the closest Senate races of the 2014 midterms. This is her second campaign appearance for a candidate, and she is expected to inject momentum into the race. Braley is running against Republican Joni Ernst, who has gained popularity with ads and endorsements. The race is considered a toss-up, and the First Lady's appearance may be an attempt to boost Braley's chances. The President's low approval rating in Iowa may be a factor in the First Lady's decision to campaign instead of her husband.

Sure! Here is the story in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Anes Subasic, a naturalized US citizen from Bosnia, was found guilty of terrorism charges, including conspiracy to murder and provide material support to terrorists. He is the seventh member of a North Carolina group convicted of terror activities. The group, led by Daniel Boyd, aimed to provide money, weapons training, and personnel to advance violent jihad abroad. Subasic and others viewed their own country as the enemy, according to FBI officials. He faces up to life in prison at sentencing in August.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Christine Rougoor, a 25-year-old woman from Ontario, Canada, won a charity contest and went bungee jumping in Whistler, British Columbia. Despite being paralyzed from the waist down since a motocross accident in 2008, Rougoor screamed with joy as she was hoisted over the bridge railing and bounced up and down several times. The experience was liberating and Rougoor would do it again in a heartbeat. The charity contest was organized by 9Lives Adventures, which helps people with disabilities live out their extreme sports dreams.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

The 2014 midterm elections brought several historic firsts, including Tim Scott becoming the first African American from the South elected to the Senate since Reconstruction. Mia Love became the first black Republican woman elected to Congress, and Joni Ernst became the first female combat veteran elected to the Senate. Shelley Moore Capito became the first woman elected to the Senate from West Virginia, and Tom Cotton became the first Iraq War veteran elected to the Senate. The election also marked a record number of women in Congress, with Gina Raimondo becoming Rhode Island's first female governor. Additionally, Elise Stefanik became the youngest woman ever elected to Congress.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A helicopter crash in western Afghanistan killed 10 Americans, including seven U.S. service members and three U.S. civilians, on Monday. The crash, which occurred in Badghis province, also injured 14 Afghan service members, 11 U.S. service members, and one U.S. civilian. The U.S. Army attributed the crash to low visibility due to thick dust, and ruled out enemy fire as the cause. This was one of two fatal incidents involving helicopters on Monday, with a total of 14 Americans killed, the largest number in a single day in over four years.

Candace Eloph had been searching for her half-brother, given up for adoption in 1977, for years. She found him living across the street, and their reunion was a surprise for both families. Jamie Wheat's adoptive parents were excited about the new stage in their son's life, and he plans to make up for lost time. The DNA test confirmed their relationship with a 99.995% probability. Eloph and Wheat are now reunited with their birth mother, Joellen Cottrell, who had always searched for her son.

Here's the story in under 150 words, while maintaining coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

In a Red Chair interview, George Clinton shares the secret to his longevity: his music and fans. The 70-year-old P-Funk mastermind still performs and tours after decades, and his energy is infectious. He credits his numerous bandmates throughout the years, including Bootsy Collins, for keeping him going. Clinton also fights piracy issues to protect artists' work. He advises others to say "no" to drugs and focus on their craft. Despite some regrets, Clinton is healthy, energetic, and hopes to continue doing what he loves for years to come.

Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands will abdicate on April 30, her 33rd anniversary of her coronation, to make way for her son Prince Willem-Alexander. In a televised speech, she assured the Dutch people that she will still be able to meet them and thanked them for their faith in her over the years. The 75-year-old queen will be succeeded by her oldest son, who is fully prepared for the task. The queen praised her husband, Prince Claus, who passed away in 2002, for his support and expressed her confidence in her son's ability to serve the country with devotion.

Marco Antonio Delgado, a prominent Texas attorney and former university trustee, has been charged with laundering over $600 million for a Mexican drug cartel. He was arrested at a restaurant in El Paso and faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted. Delgado had been active in the local community, donating to organizations such as the El Paso Symphony Orchestra and setting up a scholarship for Latino students at Carnegie Mellon University. His lawyer maintains his innocence.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez has ordered an investigation into the death of Simon Bolivar, the country's founding father, after exhuming his skeletal remains. Chavez suspects foul play and has called for a DNA test on the remains and clothing found in the tomb. The broadcast of the exhumation on state television showed the skeleton of Bolivar, who died in 1830, with Chavez singing the national anthem in the background. Chavez has long credited Bolivar as his revolutionary inspiration and has described him as "the father of the revolution."

Here's the story in under 150 words, while maintaining coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Four people were killed and nine injured in clashes in Saudi Arabia's Qatif region. The violence began on Monday and escalated during a funeral procession. The Interior Ministry blamed "unknown criminal sources" for the casualties. Shiite protesters earlier this year demanded the release of prisoners and more rights, but the government has not responded. The ongoing tension in the region may be linked to the conflict in nearby Bahrain and the rivalry between Sunni and Shiite nations.

A wildfire in Michigan's Upper Peninsula has destroyed 97 structures, including 34 homes, a motel, and a store. The Duck Lake Fire has burned over 22,000 acres and is still not contained, despite recent rains. Crews have set up 40 miles of firelines to control the blaze, but a lack of roads in the area has complicated efforts. The fire started from lightning late Wednesday and was fueled by strong winds and high temperatures. The state has banned outdoor burning in 49 counties to prevent more wildfires.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Zack Brown, a man from Columbus, Ohio, started a Kickstarter campaign to raise $10 to make potato salad for the first time. Despite his lack of experience and lukewarm forecast, the campaign quickly gained traction and raised nearly $5,000 from 850 backers. Brown's promise of a "thank you" and potato-salad themed haiku for $20 backers and a signed jar of mayonnaise for $50 backers contributed to the campaign's success. The new goal of inviting the "entire Internet" to taste the potato salad was set at $3,000, but Brown may need to make multiple batches to fulfill the demand. The campaign's success highlights the power of crowd-funding and the appeal of simple, everyday recipes that bring people together.

Kanye West demanded that all audience members stand during his concert in Sydney, threatening to stop the show if anyone remained seated. He singled out two individuals who were not standing and questioned their ability to do so. The stunt was met with backlash on Twitter, with critics accusing West of being insensitive to those with disabilities. This is not the first time West has been criticized for making similar demands at his concerts.

The English Premier League will use vanishing spray, a biodegradable foam, to mark 10-yard zones for free kicks in the 2014/15 season. The spray, which was successful at the FIFA World Cup, will help referees and improve the game. Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore and Professional Game Match Officials Limited general manager Mike Riley support the move. The spray has been used in MLS for several years and has been praised by players and fans.

A private jet crashed near Freeport, Bahamas, killing all nine people on board, including well-known pastor Myles Munroe and his wife Ruth. The cause of the crash is not yet clear, but the Federal Aviation Administration will investigate. The Global Leadership Forum, which was scheduled to start on Monday, will continue as planned, according to Munroe's organization. Andrew Young, a former US ambassador to the UN, confirmed the identities of the victims and expressed his condolences to the families.

The U.S. Open will finally get a retractable roof over Arthur Ashe Stadium, with the project expected to cost over $100 million. The roof will be in place by 2017, and will bring an end to the tournament's weather-related woes, which have caused Monday finals in recent years. The project will also include new and bigger show courts, and the overall cost is expected to hit $550 million. The men's governing body in the U.S. will self-finance the project through a combination of bonds and revenue generation. The news is welcomed by players like Serena Williams, who have been affected by the rain delays in recent years. However, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga has pulled out of this year's tournament due to a knee injury.

Malaysia Airlines is facing another public relations and financial blow after the crash of Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine, just 131 days after the disappearance of Flight 370. The loss of two Boeing 777s in such a short period could be a fatal blow to the airline, which is already struggling with financial troubles and criticism over its handling of the previous disaster. The airline's main shareholder is considering restructuring and taking it private, and the Malaysian government may need to step in with a rescue plan to save the company. The airline's handling of the two incidents will be crucial in redeeming itself and regaining the trust of passengers and their families.

A wind turbine blade was destroyed in Lincolnshire, England, and a local tabloid, The Sun, attributed the damage to a UFO. Witnesses reported seeing strange lights in the sky, and an expert suggested that the blade may have been struck by ice thrown from a neighboring turbine. However, the Guardian revealed that the lights were actually fireworks from a family celebration. The incident has sparked debate over whether the damage was caused by a UFO or a simple mechanical failure.

A mayoral candidate in Paris has proposed transforming the city's disused metro stations into unique spaces such as swimming pools, nightclubs, and art installations. The proposals include a theater and restaurant, as well. While the idea has gained attention, Kosciusko-Morizet still trails behind the frontrunner in the mayoral race.

The trial of Kaing Guek Eav, a former prison chief with the Khmer Rouge movement, resumed in a Cambodian courtroom on Monday. Prosecutors accused him of overseeing the torture and killing of over 15,000 people, including military officials and Communist Party members, at a prison he ran. The trial, which is being held in a packed courtroom, is significant because it is the first time a former Khmer Rouge leader is facing justice for the regime's atrocities. Duch has admitted his role in the regime's genocidal reign, but prosecutors are seeking a conviction on charges of crimes against humanity, war crimes, torture, and murder. The trial is expected to last three or four months, and if convicted, Duch faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. The trial is a significant step towards bringing justice to the victims of the Khmer Rouge's regime, which swept to power in 1975 and killed nearly one-quarter of Cambodia's population.

He cooperated with U.S. authorities and provided valuable intelligence on terrorist activities, which led to a reduced sentence. These festivals showcase the versatility and creativity of local cuisine, with events like mashed potato wrestling and turnip float parades. Some festivals have a historical significance, like the giant omelet celebration in France, while others are simply a fun and messy way to celebrate local food traditions. Whether it's Spam cheesecake or scorpion tastings, these festivals offer a taste of the unique and the bizarre.

The space shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week on a mission to the international space station. The shuttle will carry a crew of seven astronauts and equipment to the space station. One astronaut, Nicole Stott, will remain on the space station as a flight engineer, while the others will return to Earth aboard the shuttle. Google is launching a new version of Google Glass, its wearable technology device, for current testers (called "Explorers"). The new Glass will work with eyeglasses or shades and include an ear bud to improve sound quality. Testers can invite up to three friends to join the program and purchase the device for $1,500. The new Glass is expected to be available to the general public next year. The current testers will have 60 days to decide if they want the new Glass or keep their current model. The new Glass is designed to work with other eyeglasses, but it's not clear how the overall design will be tweaked.

The investigation is ongoing, and officials have stated that the men had no ill intent against the United States. Despite making up approximately 600 million of the world's Catholics, women will have no direct say in the selection of the next pope. The 115 cardinals voting for the pope are all men. The myth of Pope Joan, a ninth-century Englishwoman who disguised herself as a priest, has been used to boost calls for women priests. However, historians say the story is nonsense. Women do hold important lay positions in Catholic organizations, but the church's hierarchy remains male-dominated. Some believe there was once a female pope, but there are no plans to introduce female priests or a female pope anytime soon.

A Maryland man who received a kidney transplant in 2011 has died of rabies, and three other recipients of organs from the same donor are being treated for the disease. The donor, a 20-year-old airman, had died of rabies before his organs were harvested and transplanted into the four recipients. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has confirmed that the donor had rabies, which is spread by raccoons. The recipients are being treated with rabies vaccine and immune globulin, and health authorities are looking for family members or health care workers who may have had close contact with the donor or the recipient who died. The CDC is also reviewing its policies on testing donors for rabies, as the disease is extremely rare but can be fatal.

African-American atheists exist, but are often overlooked in media representation. Black atheists face challenges in discussing religion objectively due to heavy religious influence in their communities. The internet has made it easier for black atheists to connect and find support. While progress has been made in diverse representation, there is still a need for more support systems and inclusivity in secular events and organizations. The number of visible minority atheists is small but growing, and they will continue to lead the charge for change and recognition.

Survivors of the sunken South Korean ferry visited their school in Ansan, where they sobbed as they walked past images of their classmates. The tragedy has killed at least 228 passengers, with 74 still missing. The country's president has apologized for the initial response to the disaster, as investigations into the sinking continue. Three people have been arrested for destroying evidence related to the probe. The ferry disaster has left a devastating impact on the nation's psyche, with many families still waiting for news of their loved ones.

BP has implemented new safety systems for offshore drilling, ahead of its competitors, according to the company's president of Gulf of Mexico operations. The changes were made in response to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster and include a new unit monitoring wells and a training facility to teach engineers and supervisors how to manage possible leaks. The company is facing challenges in other parts of the world and sees the US as central to its future growth. However, the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon still overshadows the company's prospects, with the US Department of Justice accusing BP of gross negligence in the accident.
